ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC PWENCODE IN='password' <OUT=fileref> <METHOD=encoding-method>;
  
The PWENCODE procedure enables you to encode passwords. Encoded passwords can be used 
in place of plaintext passwords in SAS programs that access relational database management 
systems (RDBMSs) and various servers, such as SAS/CONNECT servers, SAS/SHARE servers, and 
SAS Integrated Object Model (IOM) servers (such as the SAS Metadata Server).

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: IN='password'] 
      
Specifies the password to encode. The password can contain up to a maximum of 512 
characters, which include alphanumeric characters, spaces, and special characters.

[Syntax: OUT=fileref] 
      
Specifies a fileref to which the output string is to be written. If the OUT= option 
is not specified, the output string is written to the SAS log.

Beginning in SAS 9.3, the global macro variable _PWENCODE is set to the value that 
is written to the OUT= fileref or to the value that is displayed in the SAS log.

Specifies the encoding method.
      
Beginning in SAS 9.3, if the METHOD= option is omitted, the default encoding method 
is used. When the FIPS 140-2 compliance option, -encryptfips, is specified, the 
encoding default method is sas003. For all other cases, encoding method sas002 is 
the default method used.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses a 32-bit key to encode passwords. This is the default.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Uses a 256-bit key to encode passwords.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Uses a 256-bit key plus 64-bit salt value to encode passwords.
